results.headline: ‘The Weird World of Blowfly’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Weird World of Blowfly

results.summary_short: “The Weird World of Blowfly,” traces the musician Clarence Reid’s career as his alter ego Blowfly.

results.headline: ‘Sound It Out’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sound It Out

results.summary_short: In “Sound It Out” Jeanie Finlay profiles the last record store in Teesside, England, and the loyalists who keep it alive (and vice versa).

results.headline: ‘Shut Up Little Man!’
results.display_title: Shut Up Little Man! An Audio Misadventure

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shut Up Little Man! An Audio Misadventure

results.summary_short: Matthew Bate’s “Shut Up Little Man!” is a dandy little documentary.

results.headline: She’s Dying Gracefully, and It’s Killing Him

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Restless

results.summary_short: Gus Van Sant’s “Restless” stars Mia Wasikowska as a saintly dying girl spending her last days with a depressing, angry young man.

results.headline: ‘Prince of Swine’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Prince of Swine

results.summary_short: Nell Ruttledge plays a young lawyer on a legal crusade to make a misogynistic producer and his ilk pay for their ways in “Prince of Swine.”

results.headline: ‘One Fall’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Fall

results.summary_short: Marcus Dean Fuller stars in and directed “One Fall,” about a man with who impossibly survives a fall from a cliff and develops healing powers.

results.headline: ‘My Afternoons With Margueritte’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Afternoons with Margueritte

results.summary_short: Gérard Depardieu is the village idiot who is transformed by a literary old woman in “My Afternoons With Margueritte.”

results.headline: Even a Things-to-Do List Seems to Be Multitasking
results.display_title: I Don't Know How She Does It

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Don't Know How She Does It

results.summary_short: In “I Don’t Know How She Does It,” Sarah Jessica Parker portrays a woman who “has it all,” though the movie inadvertently makes her character’s supposedly golden life look like a living hell.

results.headline: A Veneer to Hide Crumbling Poise

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy, Happy

results.summary_short: Wearing a satirical smirk, “Happy, Happy” sets out to puncture the clichéd image of Scandinavians as rosy-cheeked choristers bonded in communal togetherness.

results.headline: Fasten Your Seat Belts, the Chevy Is Taking Off

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drive

results.summary_short: “Drive,” directed by Nicolas Winding Refn, is about an unnamed virtuoso driver, played by Ryan Gosling, and his Chevy Impala getaway car.

results.headline: ‘Berlin 36’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Berlin '36

results.summary_short: “Berlin 36” loosely recounts how the Nazis plotted to keep a Jew off the German Olympic team in 1936.

results.headline: His Credit Cards and Fancy Words Can’t Help Him Here

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Straw Dogs

results.summary_short: Rod Lurie’s remake of Sam Peckinpah’s “Straw Dogs” moves the story from England to Mississippi.

results.headline: Upheaval in a Family That Hopes to Stand Out

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Position Among the Stars

results.summary_short: Leonard Retel Helmrich’s documentary “Position Among the Stars” completes his trilogy about an Indonesian family.

results.headline: Creating a Cinematic Picture of a Flemish Masterpiece

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Mill and the Cross

results.summary_short: In “The Mill and the Cross” Lech Majewski makes a film about a painting by Pieter Bruegel the Elder, “The Way to Calvary.”

results.headline: A Return to Guatemala’s Civil War, in Black and White
results.display_title: Granito: How to Nail A Dictator

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Granito: How to Nail A Dictator

results.summary_short: In “Granito: How to Nail a Dictator” Pamela Yates follows up on her earlier film, “When the Mountains Tremble.”

results.headline: A Bollywood Bride, but Who’s the Groom?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mere Brother Ki Dulhan

results.summary_short: The romantic comedy “My Brother’s Bride” centers on a heroine who is a far cry from her demure sisters of yore.

results.headline: Making the Most of the Very Least, and Other Lessons
results.display_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star

results.summary_short: “Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star” follows a dreamer who discovers a physical characteristic that helps make him an unlikely success in pornographic films.

results.headline: In a City’s Plague Years, Caring for Their Own

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Were Here

results.summary_short: “We Were Here” is an unblinking chronology of the AIDS epidemic, recounted by five people who lived through it and watched countless friends and lovers die.

results.headline: A Tale of Jacob, Esau and Muscles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Warrior

results.summary_short: Gavin O’Connor’s “Warrior” follows two estranged brothers who are separately preparing for a mixed martial arts tournament.

results.headline: For María and José, All Work and No Play

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Inheritors

results.summary_short: In “The Inheritors,” Mexican children toil in the countryside, and look forward to ever more of the same.
